Tech Sergeant Corey Turner || Train 60 crewmembers were [[C-130 Hercules]] instructors for the newly formed [[Iraqi Air Force]]. The crew's unprecedented mission was to act as the inaugural Iraqi "Air Force One" and take the [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Iraq Prime Minister]] from [[Baghdad]] to Al Sulaymania to meet with Kurdish leaders. During the mission, Train 60 crewmembers instructed Iraqi aircrew members on flight procedures in a combat environment, quickly improvised a low-level route through mountains to avoid low ceilings and landed on a taxi way at an uncontrolled and uncompleted Iraqi airfield that did not have an American security presence. Their efforts ensured the safety of the all Iraqi crew and the Iraqi head of state during this landmark airlift event. |- |

|| Captain Scott Markle || [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10]] pilot Captain Markle was diverted to support [[special forces]] troops along the [[Afghanistan]]-[[Pakistan]] border in contact with [[Taliban]] forces. He arrived just before dawn and heavy gunfire and [[Tracer ammunition|tracers]] and poor visibility made it difficult to find the team's location. Captain Markle, unable to employ weapons due to the enemy's close proximity to the team, flew a dangerously low pass over the area while releasing self-protection [[Flare (countermeasure)|flares]]. When flares momentarily halted enemy fire. The ground controller requested a few more close passes to the special forces team time to create more distance between themselves and the Taliban. The seporation allowed Captain Markle to strafe the enemy area with more than 1,000 [[GAU-8 Avenger|30 millimeter]] rounds on his final pass. The special forces team was able to disengage with no casualties. Captain Markle was credited with destroying three [[machine gun]] nests and killing 40 enemy combatants. |- |

Staff Sergeant Tim Philpott ||The crews of "Pedro 15" and "Pedro 16" operating [[HH-60G Pavehawk]]s came under enemy fire 29 July 2009 during a medical evacuation mission as part of the 129th Expeditionary Rescue Squadron at [[Kandahar Air Base]], [[Afghanistan]]. Three Soldiers had been wounded near [[Forward Operating Base]] Frontenac when their convoy was hit with an [[improvised explosive device]] and became engaged by enemy combatants. During the recovery operation "Pedro 15" was downed by enemy fire, injuring the crew. "Pedro 16", along with Army [[OH-58 Kiowa]]s, suppressed enemy fire. Captain Rosebrough developed a plan to evacuate all the wounded personnel aboard "Pedro 16" and two Kiowa helicopters. Their efforts ensured the recovery of the six "Pedro 15" crew members and three wounded soldiers. |} ===2010s=== {| border=1 style="border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor=cccccc !width=5%|Year!!width=20%|Awardee!!width=20%|Action |- |

Tsougas || While operating as a flight of two [[F-15E Strike Eagle]]s - call signs Dude 01 and Dude 02 - they were tasked to support a Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force team surrounded by over 100 enemy fighters in the town of Bala Morgab, [[Afghanistan]]. With weather below rescue force launch minimums, Dude flight used [[terrain-following radar]] to execute five "Show of Force" passes in a valley surrounded by high terrain. When hostilities escalated, Dude Flight expertly employed six [[Joint Direct Attack Munition]]s, helping kill over 80 [[Taliban]] fighters who occupied reinforced positions within the town. Their efforts helped save the lives of approximately 30 coalition troops. There were no civilian casualties. |- |

Senior Airman Jordan J. Dehlbom ||The members and crew of Pedro 83 Flight distinguished themselves an Air Force [[Combat search and rescue]] aircrew from November 1, 2011 to February 8, 2012. In January 2012, Pedro 83 Flight, launched in response to a [[MEDEVAC]] call near [[Mazar-e-Sharif]], Afghanistan. The flight navigated through low visibility to reach the patient. Hoye ||The crews of Rooster 73 flight distinguished themselves as [[Bell Boeing V-22 Osprey|CV-22]] Pilots and Flight Engineers with the 8th Expeditionary Special Operations Squadron, on December 21, 2013 while in support of Noncombatant Evacuation Operations in the vicinity of [[Bor, South Sudan|Bor]], [[South Sudan]]. On approach to land, the flight took heavy surface-to-air fire, resulting in damage to multiple aircraft systems. The damage caused multiple fuel leaks requiring emergency airborne refueling to allow for the safe return of all three battle damaged aircraft, crew, and passengers. Damage to the aircraft required crew members to manually extend refueling probes and activate emergency aerial refueling valves to enable multiple refueling tracks to take on enough fuel to reach [[Entebbe]]. Time critical decision making, outstanding airmanship, and extraordinary [[crew resource management]] allowed the members of Rooster 73 Flight to save 34 aircrew and three $89 million aircraft.{{cite web|last1=Feather|first1=Melodie |title=United States Air Force Crews of Rooster 73 Flight Awarded the Mackay Trophy for 2013.|url=https://naa.aero/userfiles/files/documents/Press%20Releases/Mackay%202013%20PR.pdf|accessdate=18 June 2015}} |- |
2014
|'''THE CREW OF IRONHAND 41 FLIGHT''' Captain Gregory R. Balzhiser
Captain David A. Kroontje |The aircrew of the Pacific Air Forces` Ironhand 41 flight, orchestrated four flawless attacks during an eight-hour night, flying F-16Cs over 500 miles in enemy-controlled terrain. Their attacks destroyed three Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) blockades, multiple armored vehicles, one observation post, and killed ISIL fighters who were firing upon 40,000 trapped Yazidi civilians who had fled to Mount Sinjar. Their outstanding battle management caused the cessation of ISIL indirect fires on civilians, ended ISIL freedom of movement around Mount Sinjar, facilitated the evacuation corridor by reducing pressure on Peshmerga ground forces, and ultimately saved the lives of 40,000 civilians including women, children, elderly, and the infirm. |- |
2015
|'''THE CREWS OF WEASEL 41 AND WEASEL 51 FLIGHT''' Lieutenant Colonel Jeffrey Cohen
Major Seth Taylor
Captain Danielle Kangas
Captain Mathew Park
|On July 26, 2015, United States Air Force Lieutenant Colonel Jeffrey Cohen, Major Seth Taylor, Captain Danielle Kangas, and Captain Mathew Park, arrived on scene over Hassekah, a major city in northeast Syria, where friendly Syrian Kurdish ground units were battling the last significant holdout of a group of Islamic State enemy personnel. A firefight in the southeast portion of the city had erupted, pinning Kurdish ground units in a dense urban city block. Overcoming targeting complicated by weather and limited communications, Lieutenant Colonel Cohen and Major Taylor expertly coordinated and employed several successful munitions in support of Kurdish forces despite highly restrictive attack parameters. Captain Kangas and Captain Park tracked and executed an effective attack on fleeing enemy soldiers wearing blankets to reduce their infrared signature. In a four-hour period, the crews of WEASEL 41 and WEASEL 51 flight employed 15 precision guided munitions, destroying eight enemy fighting positions, with no friendly or civilian casualties. This marked the end of a three-month operation in Northern Syria that resulted in friendly Kurdish forces retaking over 17 thousand square kilometers of territory, securing the Syria/Turkey border between Iraq and the Euphrates River. |- |
2016
|'''THE CREW OF SPOOKY 43 FLIGHT''' Major Alexander Hill
Major Aaron Hall
Captain Garrett Robinson
1st Lt. Zachary Hanley
1st Lt. Marshall Shefler
Staff Sgt. William Cody
Staff Sgt. Freddie Coffee
Staff Sgt. Cody Flora
Staff Sgt. David Kerns Jr.
Staff Sgt. Timothy Lewis
Staff Sgt. Alexander Skidgel
Senior Airman Kellen Lloyd
Senior Airman Jonathan Russell
Airman 1st Class Raymond Bourne |On November 2, 2016, the crew of SPOOKY 43 was tasked to provide close air support and armed reconnaissance for a 55-man combined American and Afghan special operations team conducting a raid to interdict insurgent command and control nodes, senior leadership, and their networks. After the crew of SPOOKY 43 arrived overhead, the combined American and Afghan special operations force (also referred to as “friendlies”) was caught in a deadly ambush by a large insurgent force. The friendlies were engaged by small arms, heavy machine gun, and grenade fire from multiple defensive fighting positions. The crew of SPOOKY 43 provided close air support to the friendly ground force with the 25, 40, and 105-millimeter guns, to allow the them the freedom to maneuver and provide care for casualties. In order to protect the ground team from enemy personnel, the crew of SPOOKY 43 expertly employed the 105-millimeter gun at an unprecedented 12 meters from the friendly personnel. Due to the outstanding airmanship and bravery under extremely challenging circumstances, SPOOKY 43 destroyed 10 defensive fighting positions, 27 enemy insurgents, and three enemy technical vehicles, saving the lives of 50 combined American and Afghan special operations forces personnel who would have otherwise perished in the enemy ambush. The professional ability and outstanding aerial accomplishments of the crew of SPOOKY 43 reflect credit upon themselves and the United States Air Force. |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{Portal|United States Air Force}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070228080436/http://www.naa.aero/html/awards/index.cfm?cmsid=70 National Aeronautic Association Mackay Trophy Page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071110083454/http://www.ascho.wpafb.af.mil/birthplace/AWARD3.HTM ASC Award Winners; Mackay Trophy] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060901071348/http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/trophy/mackay.cfm Smithsonian Aeronautics Division Awards and Trophies] [[Category:Awards and decorations of the United States Air Force]] [[Category:Aviation awards]] [[Category:Mackay Trophy winners| ]]

{{Infobox person | name = Michael Cudahy | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1841|12|07|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Callan, County Kilkenny]], Ireland | death_date = {{death date and age|1910|11|27|1841|12|07|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]], U.S. | resting_place = Calvary Cemetery, [[Evanston, Illinois]] | residence = | nationality = Irish-American | occupation = Industrialist | spouse = {{marriage|Catharine Sullivan|1866|1910}} | children = 7 | relatives = [[Patrick Cudahy]] (brother)
[[Edward Cudahy, Jr.]] (nephew)
[[John Cudahy]] (nephew)
[[Michael Cudahy (electronics)|Michael Cudahy]] (great-nephew)}} '''Michael Cudahy''' (December 7, 1841 – November 27, 1910) was an American industrialist who, along with two brothers, established the [[Cudahy Packing Company]] in 1890. ==Early life== Cudahy was born in [[Callan, County Kilkenny]] in 1841 to Patrick and Elizabeth (née Shaw) Cudahy. The family emigrated to the [[United States]] in 1849, and eventually settled in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]].{{cite book|last=Ingham|first=John N. |title=Biographical Dictionary of American Business Leaders |volume=1|year=1983 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=0-313-21362-3|page=222}}[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/dictionary/index.asp?action=view&term_id=1213& Cudahy, Patrick entry], ''Dictionary of Wisconsin History'', Wisconsin Historical Society website; accessed October 1, 2014.[http://www.livestockexpo.org/ssclub/ssbook_pdfs/abc.pdf "Saddle and Sirloin Portrait Catalogue"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703183359/http://www.livestockexpo.org/ssclub/ssbook_pdfs/abc.pdf |date=2008-07-03 }}, livestockexpo.org; accessed October 1, 2014.Sherman, Jeff. [http://staff.onmilwaukee.com/buzz/articles/cudahy.html "Milwaukee Talks: Michael Cudahy"], OnMilwaukee.com, August 28, 2002. ==Career== Cudahy dropped out of school at age 14 and found a job working at Layton and Plankinton, Milwaukee, an area [[meat packing]] plant. He worked his way up the ranks and eventually became a private meat inspector. By 1869, Cudahy was a manager in charge of the packing house at Plankinton, Armour and Company, which had been established in Milwaukee in 1852. In 1873, he was made partner in [[Armour and Company]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SwQlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hxEGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2043,1210066&dq=michael+cudahy+obituary&hl=en|title=MICHAEL CUDAHY PASSES|date=1910-12-02|work=The New Era|page=2|accessdate=December 10, 2012}} With the help of his brothers [[Patrick Cudahy|Edward and Patrick]], he established the Cudahy Packing Company in [[South Omaha, Nebraska]] in 1890. ===Real estate=== By the late 19th century, Cudahy had become a wealthy man living a comfortable life. He took an interest in [[Mackinac Island, Michigan]] as a summer home. He also owned a home in Hubbard's Annex on the island in the late 19th century, which he later sold to his brother Edward. He then went to California in 1897 and traded in real estate to expand his fortune. {{citation needed|date=October 2014}} He returned to Mackinac Island in 1904 and bought {{convert|150|acre|km2}}, making him one of the largest landowners on Mackinac Island. In 1908, Cudahy sold his share of the Cudahy Meatpacking Company and acquired a 2,800 acre (11 km²) [[Rancho San Antonio (Lugo)|Rancho San Antonio]] east of [[Los Angeles, California]]. He subdivided the ranch and sold it as one acre (4,000 m²) lots. This area was incorporated in 1960 as the City of [[Cudahy, California|Cudahy]].{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} Cudahy handpicked renowned architect Frederick Wainwright Perkins to fulfill his visions of a West Bluff mansion. Perkins also designed the Governors Mansion on the island. In 1904, construction was completed on his mansion which he named Stonecliffe which was the largest private home on Mackinac Island. It went through a number of owners after Cudahy's death in 1910. In 1970, Stonecliffe was purchased by an entrepreneur named George Staffan who converted the mansion and associated buildings into a first class resort hotel called The Inn at Stonecliffe in which capacity it continues to function to this day. ==Personal life== In 1866, Cudahy married Catharine Sullivan. The couple had seven children, four boys and three girls. ==Death== On November 27, 1910, Cudahy died of [[Acute lung injury|double pneumonia]] at a [[Chicago]] hospital. He is buried in Calvary Cemetery in [[Evanston, Illinois]].{{cite book|last=Gibbs|first=Michelle |title=Generations Of Pride: A Centennial History of Cudahy, Wisconsin|year=2006|publisher=Reminder Printing, Inc.|isbn=0-9791768-0-8|page=473}} ==See also== * [[History of Omaha]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Find a Grave|8672605|name=Michael Cudahy}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cudahy, Michael}} [[Category:1841 births]] [[Category:1910 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Irish people]] [[Category:19th-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:American industrialists]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Cudahy family]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in Illinois]] [[Category:People from County Kilkenny]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles County, California]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:Irish emigrants to the United States (before 1923)]] [[Category:Catholics from California]] [[Category:Catholics from Nebraska]]

{{Infobox person | name = Oliver Harriman Jr. | image = File:Oliver_Harriman_Jr_Passport_photo_1921.jpg | image_size = | caption = Oliver Harriman Jr. in 1921 | birth_name = | birth_date = November 29, 1862 | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1940|8|14|1862|11|29}} | death_place = [[Silver Spring, Maryland]], U.S. | death_cause = | resting_place = [[White Plains, New York]], U.S. | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = 70 [[Park Avenue]], [[Manhattan]], New York City, U.S.
White Plains, New York, U.S.
Silver Spring, Maryland, U.S. | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater= [[Princeton University]] | employer = | occupation = Stockbroker | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = Grace Carley | children = Oliver Carley Harriman, John Harriman, Borden Harriman | parents = [[Oliver Harriman]]
Laura Low | relatives = [[Anne Harriman Vanderbilt]] (sister)
[[J. Borden Harriman]] (brother)
[[Herbert M. Harriman]] (brother)
[[E. H. Harriman]] (cousin) | box_width = }} '''Oliver Harriman Jr.''' (1862–1940) was an American heir and stockbroker. ==Early life== Oliver Harriman Jr. was born on November 29, 1862 in [[New York City]].{{cite book |last=Harrison |first=Mitchell Charles |date=1902 |title=Prominent and Progressive Americans: An Encyclopædia of Contemporaneous Biography |url=https://archive.org/stream/prominentprogres00harr#page/149/mode/2up |location=New York City |publisher= New York Tribune |pages=150–151 |oclc=12266525}} His father, [[Oliver Harriman]], was a dry goods businessman. His mother was Laura Low. He had four brothers and three sisters. Harriman attended [[Princeton University]], where he was a member of the [[Ivy Club]], and graduated in 1883. ==Career== Harriman started his career at [[Winslow, Lanier & Co.]], an investment firm in New York City, where he worked from 1883 to 1888. He became a partner in Harriman & Co. in 1888. Harriman served on the Board of Directors of the [[Continental Trust Company of New York]]. ==Personal life== Harriman married Grace Carley of [[Louisville, Kentucky]] on January 28, 1891.{{cite web |url=https://www.nyhistory.org/exhibit/mrs-oliver-harriman-jr-1873-1950 |title=Mrs. Oliver Harriman, Jr. (1873-1950) |website=[[New-York Historical Society]] |access-date=November 20, 2015}}{{cite news | author = | title= Three Weddings of Note | url =https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1891/01/29/103293024.pdf | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York, New York | date = January 29, 1891 | access-date = November 20, 2015}} They had three sons, including Oliver Carley Harriman. They resided at 70 [[Park Avenue]] on the island of [[Manhattan]] in New York City,{{cite news|title=Xmas Gift For Mrs Oliver Harriman, Jr.? |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/87167628/?terms=%22Oliver%2BHarriman%2C%2BJr.%22 |newspaper=The Brooklyn Daily Eagle |location=Brooklyn, New York |date=December 27, 1902 |page=8 |via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = December 9, 2015 }} {{Open access}} and they summered in [[White Plains, New York]]. They also owned a residence in [[Silver Spring, Maryland]].{{cite news|title=Oliver Harriman, 77, Ex-Broker, Dies |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/52647398/?spot=2172439 |newspaper=The Sun |location=New York, New York |date=August 14, 1940 |page=1|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = November 20, 2015 }} {{Open access}} Harriman served in the [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard of New York]] from 1888 onward. He was a member of the [[University Club of New York]], the [[Metropolitan Club]], the [[Knickerbocker Club]], the [[New York Yacht Club]], and the [[Westchester Country Club]]. His wife became a philanthropist, serving as president of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries and the Camp Fire Girls. Additionally, she joined the Southern Women's Democratic Club. Her miniature portrait was done by [[Meave Thompson Gedney]] circa 1900 for art collector [[Peter Marié]]. ==Death== Harriman died on August 14, 1940 in Silver Spring, Maryland.{{cite news | author = | title= Oliver Harriman, Stock Broker, Dies | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1940/08/15/93988117.pdf | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York, New York | date = August 15, 1940 | access-date = November 20, 2015}} His funeral was held in White Plains, New York, where he was buried. His widow died a decade later, on March 28, 1950.{{cite news | author = | title= Mrs. Harriman, 77, Civic Leader, Dead | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1950/03/29/113149777.pdf | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York, New York | date = March 29, 1950 | access-date = November 20, 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harriman, Oliver Jr.}} [[Category:1862 births]] [[Category:1940 deaths]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:People from White Plains, New York]] [[Category:People from Silver Spring, Maryland]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:American stockbrokers]] [[Category:Harriman family]]

'''Patricia Aragon Santo Tomas''' is the Chairman of the Board of [[Development Bank of the Philippines]] since 2006.
She has been a Secretary of Labor and Employment and Chairwoman of the [[Civil Service Commission (Philippines)|Philippine Civil Service Commission]] for several years.
==Education== Patricia Aragon Santo Tomas graduated from Kamuning Elementary School and Quirino High School, both in [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]]. She received her [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from [[Far Eastern University]], her [[Master of Science]] from the [[University of the Philippines Los Baños]], and her [[Master of Public Administration]] from the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] of [[Harvard University]].<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
==Early work== Patricia Aragon Santo Tomas first worked in the government as a clerk at the [[Philippine Senate]] from 1964 to 1966. She gradually rose from the ranks and was transferred from one agency to another until her appointment as Chief of the Manpower Development and Utilization Division in the Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE) until 1977.<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
==Leadership experience== Santo Tomas held other positions as policymaker until her appointment as Administrator of the Philippine Overseas Employment Agency (POEA) from May 1982 to September 1987. She was appointed Assistant Secretary at the Department of Education, and was shortly re-appointed at the DOLE.<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
In March 1988, she was appointed Chairperson of the [[Civil Service Commission (Philippines)|Civil Service Commission]] (CSC) until March 1995. The CSC is the central personnel agency of the government of the Philippines.<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
In 2001, she led an Executive Search Committee tasked to find qualified professionals to man key positions in the Cabinet and attached agencies of President [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]]. Soon, she was appointed by President Arroyo as Secretary of the [[Department of Labor and Employment]] (DOLE).<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
Santo Tomas was elected as Chairperson of the Governing Body of the [[International Labour Organization]] based in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
In 2006, Santo Tomas was appointed by President Arroyo as Chair of the Board of Directors of the [[Development Bank of the Philippines]], a state-owned financial institution with a nationwide branch office network.<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
==Awards== Santo Tomas has received numerous professional awards for government service and public leadership. She was a Ten Outstanding Women in the Nation's Service Awardee for Public Administration; an Outstanding Graduate of the Career Executive Service Development Program Phase 2; an Edward S. Mason Fellow at [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]]; a [[Harvard University]] Fellow; a Grantee of the United States [[International Visitor Leadership Program|International Visitor Program]], and the United States International Communication Agency.<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
==Academe== Santo Tomas is a Professorial Lecturer at the [[University of the Philippines Los Baños]] and a Consultant at the Communication Technology for Rural Education.<ref>Cabinet profile, Office of the President, Republic of the Philippines, 2006.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051212140220/http://www.devbankphil.com.ph/ Development Bank of the Philippines] *[http://www.dole.gov.ph Department of Labor and Employment, Republic of the Philippines] *[http://www.ilo.org International Labour Organization]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Wikinews|An interview with Paul Campbell, founder of Amazing Radio UK}}
'''Paul Andrew Campbell''' (born 1959) is a British entrepreneur and musician. He is the founder of amazing, the [[digital media]] brand, and CEO of Amazing Media, operator of amazingtunes.com and Amazing Radio.
==Education== Campbell was born in north-east England and educated at [[RGS Newcastle]] and [[New College, Oxford]], where he read English Literature.
==Early career== Campbell started his media career as a BBC General Trainee in 1980. He became a Producer of File on 4, the BBC Radio 4 current affairs programme, in 1982. After producing BBC Television programmes such as [[Russell Harty]] and [[Brass Tacks (BBC TV series)|Brass Tacks]], he left the BBC to freelance as a TV Producer with Diverse Production and then [[Zenith Productions]] in 1987.
In 1989 he founded Bell Television, a London-based television production company which made programmes for [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky Television]] and [[Channel 4]]. Bell diversified into radio, commercials, corporate films and new media, building its first website for [[The Barbican Centre]] in 1992. It was an early adopter of desktop digital production techniques to deliver content across multiple platforms.
During the [[dot-com bubble]] Bell focused entirely on new media, working for clients such as [[Granada Television]], [[Goldman Sachs]], [[JP Morgan]] and [[UBS Warburg]]<ref name="Bell Media">{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/133123/Bell-Media-sheds-12-London-staff/ |title=Bell Media sheds 12 London staff|date=11 June 2001|accessdate=11 June 2001|publisher=Media Week}}</ref> from offices in [[Carnaby Street]], London and New York. In 2002 Campbell re-located to north-east England<ref name="The Good Life">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3109535.stm#paul|title=Striking Gold on the Tyne|date=4 August 2003|accessdate=4 August 2003|publisher=BBC}}</ref> and co-founded [[Liberty Bell Productions]]<ref name="Liberty Bell">{{cite web|url=http://icnewcastle.icnetwork.co.uk/0100news/0100local/page.cfm?objectid=12307758&method=full&siteid=50081 |title=Liberty Bell declares a war on independents|date=24 October 2002|accessdate=24 October 2002|publisher=ncjMedia}}</ref> (the TV company which produces [[Grumpy Old Men (TV series)|Grumpy Old Men]] for the BBC) with former ITV CEO [[Stuart Prebble]]<ref name="Prebble">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/oct/24/broadcasting|title=Prebble takes post at Liberty Bell|date=24 October 2002|accessdate=24 October 2002|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> and [[The Tube (TV series)|The Tube]] creator [[Andrea Wonfor]]. In 2003 he founded 'amazing'.
==Amazing== amazing started life as an educational software company, producer of the study website Amazing Grades and other online products for 14–19-year-old students. Amazing Grades was designed to speed the process of using the internet for students, combining web search results with expert input from teachers at leading British schools in both the private and state-maintained sector.<ref name="Amazing Grades">{{cite web|url=http://amazing-grades.com/corporate.aspx|title=Welcome to Amazing Grades|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=29 November 2011|publisher=Amazing Learning Ltd}}</ref>
In 2005, looking for ways to extend the amazing brand, Campbell conceived the idea of amazingtunes.com while reading a biography of [[Steve Jobs]]. The concept combined his digital media and music experience and was designed to re-shape the music industry with an ethical business model which rewarded musicians fairly for their work. 'amazingtunes.com' launched as a beta website in 2006.<ref name="Amazing Tunes Launches">{{cite web|url= http://www.music-news.com/ShowNews.asp?nItemID=16945&bPrint=1|title=Amazingtunes launches to help unsigned talent|date=21 December 2007|accessdate=29 November 2011|publisher=MusicNews.com}}</ref> In 2007 it was spun off as a separate company, The Amazing Media Group. In 2009 [[Amazing Radio]] launched,<ref name="Amazing Radio Silences Birdsong">{{cite web|url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2009/jun/01/dab-birdsong-amazing-radio-unsigned-bands|title=Amazing Radio gives voice to unsigned bands – but silences birdsong channel|date=1 June 2009|accessdate=1 June 2009|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref><ref name="Amazing Radio Launches">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/5423072/Amazing-Radio-launches-on-DAB-promoting-unsigned-talent.html |title=Amazing Radio launches on DAB, promoting unsigned talent|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|publisher=The Telegraph}}</ref><ref name="Amazing Radio Launches on DAB">{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/909735/Amazing-Radio-launches-DAB/ |title=Amazing Radio Launches on DAB|date=6 January 2009|accessdate=6 January 2009|publisher=The Telegraph}}</ref> a national digital station broadcasting 100% new music drawn from amazingtunes.com. In 2010 it launched Amazing Instore, delivering new music to shops and business premises,<ref name="Amazing Instore Launches">{{cite web|url= http://www.music-news.com/ShowNews.asp?nItemID=16945&bPrint=1|title=New instore music system keeps cost down for retailers|date=20 June 2011|accessdate=20 June 2011|publisher=Marketing Week}}</ref> and The Amazing Chart, an unsigned chart published weekly by the European music industry journal [[Music Week]].<ref name="Music Week teams up with Amazing pool of talent">{{cite web|url= http://www.musicweek.com/story.asp?storyCode=1043718&sectioncode=1|title=MW teams up with Amazing pool of talent|date=4 January 2011|accessdate=4 January 2011|publisher=Music Week}}</ref><ref name="Amazing Chart on Music Week">{{cite web|url=http://www.generator.org.uk/blog/amazing-chart-music-week|title=Amazing Chart on Music Week|date=6 January 2011|accessdate=6 January 2011|publisher=Generator}}</ref>
==Musical experience== Campbell has performed as a freelance professional musician for most of his life, playing [[timpani]], percussion and drums. He started studying aged 9, gave his professional debut aged 11 and by age 21 had played in The [[Royal Albert Hall]],<ref name="Paul Campbell plays Royal Albert Hall">{{cite web|url=http://www.sunderland.ac.uk/newsevents/news/news/index.php?nid=1317 |title=North East entrepreneur honoured|date=11 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011|publisher=University of Sunderland}}</ref> [[Royal Festival Hall]], The [[Marquee Club]] and BBC Maida Vale Studios. He now freelances part-time as a timpanist with [[Northern Sinfonia]] and other professional orchestras and plays jazz and rock drums for pleasure. He also plays the piano.
==Awards and honours== Campbell has an MA from Oxford University, is a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Arts]] and in 2011 was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Business Administration by [[Sunderland University]].<ref name="NE entrepreneur honoured">{{cite web|url= http://www.sunderland.ac.uk/newsevents/news/news/index.php?nid=1317 |title=North East entrepreneur honoured|date=11 June 2011|accessdate=11 June 2011|publisher=University of Sunderland}}</ref>
He won the [[Broadcasting Press Guild]] Award for 'outstanding radio programme' in 1984 for File on 4 and has other creative awards in a variety of electronic media, including three [[New York Film Festival]] Awards and a Communication Achievement Award for 'Excellence in the Use of Video'.
==Personal life and other activities== Campbell is a member of the [[British Association of Snowsport Instructors]], having taught skiing in the European Alps before his marriage. He is a Governor of [[Royal Grammar School, Newcastle]],<ref name="RGS Governors">{{cite web|url= http://www.rgs.newcastle.sch.uk/the-school/governing-body.php|title=Royal Grammar School Newcastle Governing Body|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=29 November 2011|publisher=Royal Grammar School Newcastle}}</ref> a Governor of Sunderland University and a founder member and Director of The Entrepreneurs' Forum,<ref name="Entrepreneurs Forum">{{cite web|url= http://www.entrepreneursforum.net/about-us/board-profiles/|title=Entrepreneurs' Forum Board Profiles|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=29 November 2011|publisher=The Entrepreneurs' Forum}}</ref> a networking association for British entrepreneurs.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.amazing-media.com Amazing Media] * [http://www.amazingtunes.com Amazing Tunes] * [http://www.amazingradio.co.uk Amazing Radio] * [http://www.amazinginstore.com Amazing Instore] * [http://www.amazing-grades.com Amazing Grades]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Campbell, Paul}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British percussionists]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British technology company founders]]

{{Infobox musical artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Rahim | honorific_suffix = | image = Pokahontaz 002.jpg | image_upright = | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = | background = solo_singer | native_name = Sebastian Salbert | native_name_lang = pl | birth_name = | alias = Rahim, Rah, Rahuene, Straho | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|11|17}} | birth_place = [[Katowice]], [[Poland]] | origin = [[Mikołów]], [[Poland]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date first) --> | death_place = | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] * [[alternative hip hop]] * [[dubstep]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * [[rapper]] * [[hip hop production|producer]] * [[entrepreneur]] }} | instrument = | years_active = 1994–present | label = {{flatlist| * S.P. Records * Gigant Records * MaxFloRec }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * 3xKlan * [[Paktofonika]] * [[Pokahontaz]] * [[Kaliber 44]] }} | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} or {{Official URL}} --> | module = | module2 = | module3 = }} '''Sebastian Salbert''' better known as '''Rahim''' (born November 17, 1978 in [[Katowice]]<ref name="dlastudenta">{{cite web|title=Rahim (Sebastian Salbert) - Biografia, Życiorys - Muzyka|url=http://muzyka.dlastudenta.pl/artysta/Rahim/biografia,9213.html|website=muzyka.dlastudenta.pl|accessdate=29 November 2017}}</ref>) is a [[Poles|Polish]] [[rapper]], [[hip hop production|producer]] and [[entrepreneur]]. He is the owner of [[record company]] MaxFloRec, the former member of groups such as 3xKlan, MZD, Erka and [[Paktofonika]]. Since 2003 He has been the one half of a duo [[Pokahontaz]] which he creates with [[Fokus (rapper)|Fokus]]. He has released several albums under his [[alter ego]] '''Straho'''.
In 2001 he, along with his then group [[Paktofonika]], received the Polish music award [[Fryderyk]] in ''Album of the year - hip-hop'' category for their album ''[[Kinematografia]]''. In 2011, magazine Machina classified him at number 25 on list of "30 best Polish rappers".
He has a younger brother, Minx, who is a [[beatbox]]er and won Polish championship in beatbox in 2007.
== Biography == Sebastian Salbert was born on November 17, 1978 in [[Katowice]]{{r|dlastudenta}}, where he spent his early childhood. He moved out to [[Mikołów]] with his family later where he lives to this day.<ref name="maxflo">{{cite web|title=Rahim - Wokaliści - Artyści - MaxFlo|url=http://maxflo.pl/Rahim.html|website=maxflo.pl|accessdate=29 November 2017}}</ref> He began to be active as an artist in 1994 when he, along with Maczo, B.U.C and DJ Bambus, formed a group 3xKlan. In 1996, he produced two track for [[Kaliber 44]]'s debut album ''[[Księga Tajemnicza. Prolog]]'' and rapped on a track "Psychodela".<ref name="ksiega">{{cite web|title=Kaliber 44 - Księga Tajemnicza. Prolog|url=https://www.discogs.com/Kaliber-44-Ksi%C4%99ga-Tajemnicza-Prolog/release/1379791|website=Discogs|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> A year later, in 1997, 3xKlan released their debut and the only album ''Dom pełen drzwi'' which stylistically and lyrically was similar to Kaliber's debut. A few tracks from the album such as "Pozytywka" and "Łza wyobraźni" gained some popularity in Poland, peaking at Szczecińska Lista Przebojów chart. The album was also nominated for the [[Fryderyk]] award in category "Album of the year – rap & hip-hop".<ref name="3xklanfryderyk">{{cite web|last1=www.onyx.pl|first1=Onyx Sp. z o.o., tel. +48 572 400 000,|title=Nominowani i laureaci :: Nagroda muzyczna - Fryderyk :: Związek Producentów Audio-Video|url=http://www.zpav.pl/fryderyk/nominowani/index.php?year=1997|website=www.zpav.pl|accessdate=1 December 2017}}</ref> Subsequently, he was a part of short-lived projects eRKa and MZD.
In 1998, after the dissolution of 3xKlan, Rahim contacted with two rappers from Katowice: [[Magik (rapper)|Magik]] and [[Fokus (rapper)|Fokus]], and after a short period of time they created a new group [[Paktofonika]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Miszczak|first1=Radek|title=Radek Miszczak: Beaty, rymy, życie: leksykon muzyki hip-hop|date=2005|publisher=Kurpisz S.A.|isbn=9788389738752|page=381|edition=Wyd. 1.}}</ref> In April 2000, the group signed a contract with Gigant Records. On 18 December 2000, the debut album ''[[Kinematografia]]'' was released. Eight days after the release, Magik committed suicide by jumping out of the window. One year after the release of ''Kinematografia'', Rahim decided to co-produce the album ''Zawieszeni w czasie i przestrzeni'' of [[side-project]] [[Pijani Powietrzem]]. The album was finally released on 2002. On September 2002, Paktofonika's second and final studio album ''[[Archiwum kinematografii]]'', containing old Magik's verses, was released. Meanwhile, he was working on his studio album ''Experyment: PSYHO'' which eventually was released on November 17, 2002 under his [[alter ego]] name Straho.
In 2003, Paktofonika performed their last show at [[Spodek]] in [[Katowice]] and on the same day Rahim, along with Fokus and DJ Bambus, announced the start of the group [[Pokahontaz]]. In 2004 he founded his own [[record label]] MaxFloRec which is the continuation of MaxFloStudio which was opened in 1998.<ref name="maxflohist">{{cite web|title=Info - O nas - MaxFlo|url=http://maxflo.pl/Info.html|website=maxflo.pl|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref> In April 2005, the group released their first studio album ''Receptura''. The album was promoted with singles "Wstrząs dla mas", "Nie1", and "Cyfroni" and it debuted at number 3 on Polish [[OLiS]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oficjalna lista sprzedaży :: OLIS - Official Retail Sales Chart|url=http://olis.onyx.pl/listy/index.asp?idlisty=254&lang=pl|website=olis.onyx.pl|accessdate=2 December 2017}}</ref> In 2006 he produced the debut album ''Miraż'' for hip-hop group Projektor.
On 2007, Rahim started collaborating with [[L.U.C]], an [[alternative hip hop]] and [[nu jazz]] artist, and on October 19, 2007 they released their joint album ''Homoxymoronomatura''. The album was promoted with singles "Hemoglobina" and "Nibyminipocieszne Psychomarionety". On November, the same year, Rahim released, as previously under his nickname Straho, his second studio album ''DynamoL''. The album features guest appearances from rappers like [[Abradab]], Grubson and the group Projektor.
A year later, he performed in a play "Szepty", directed by Jack Burban at [[Polish Theatre in Wrocław]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Wywiad z Rahimem|url=http://iwiesz24.pl/wywiad-z-rahimem|accessdate=4 December 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926145515/http://iwiesz24.pl/wywiad-z-rahimem|archive-date=2011-09-26}}</ref> In the same year, he released ''Homoxymoronomatura Live'' - a [[live album|live version]] of ''Homoxymoronomatura''. In 2010, Rahim released his first debut studio album under his normal pseudonym. The album, titled ''Podróże po amplitudzie'', was finally released on March 5, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rah!m* - Podróże Po Amplitudzie|url=https://www.discogs.com/Rahm-Podr%C3%B3%C5%BCe-Po-Amplitudzie/release/2179683|website=Discogs|accessdate=11 December 2017|language=en}}</ref> On December 6, 2010, a [[remix album]] of the album, titled ''Amplifikacja'' was released. The remixes were produced by producers such as: [[O.S.T.R]], DiNO, Vixen and others.
On 2012, Rahim, along with Fokus, were focused on working on ''[[Jesteś Bogiem]]'', a movie, directed by Leszek Dawid, which tells a story of [[Paktofonika]]. The movie was released on September 21, 2012 and received highly positive reviews. On October 19, [[Pokahontaz]] released their second studio album ''Rekontakt'' which debuted at number 2 on Polish [[OLiS]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|last1=www.onyx.pl|first1=Onyx Sp. z o.o., tel. +48 22 3377222,|title=Oficjalna lista sprzedaży :: OLIS - Official Retail Sales Chart|url=http://olis.onyx.pl/listy/index.asp?idlisty=775&lang=|website=olis.onyx.pl|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref>
== Discography == {{col-start}} {{col-2}} ; Studio albums * ''Experyment: PSYHO'' (2002) (as Straho) * ''DynamoL'' (2007) (as Straho) * ''Podróże po amplitudzie'' (2010) * ''Amplifikacja'' (2010) {{col-2}} ; Collaboration albums * ''Homoxymoronomatura'' (2007) (with [[L.U.C]]) * ''Homoxymoronomatura Live'' (2008) (with [[L.U.C]]) * ''Optymistycznie'' (2015) (with Buka) {{col-end}}

{{Infobox person | name = Recaredo Santos Tornero | image = | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1842|10|14}} | birth_place = [[Valparaíso]], [[Chile]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1902|07|26|1842|10|14}} | death_place = [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], Chile | education = | occupation = Journalist, Editor and Director of ''[[El Mercurio de Valparaíso]]'' | alias = | title = | family = | spouse = Elena Stuven Olmos | domestic_partner = | children = Carmela, Recaredo, Teresa and Enrique | relatives = | ethnicity = | nationality = Chilean | religion = | years_active= 1860<ref name="Biography">{{cite web |url = http://www.biografiadechile.cl/detalle.php?IdContenido=231&IdCategoria=8&IdArea=31&status=&TituloPagina=Historia%20de%20Chile |title = Recaredo Santos Tornero: 1842-1902. Editor y periodista |accessdate = July 2, 2010 |publisher = Biografías de Chile |language = Spanish|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ekavxo6x|archivedate=27 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref>–1902 | credits = | agent = | URL = }} '''Recaredo Santos Tornero Olmos''' (October 14, 1842 – July 26, 1902) was a [[Chilean people|Chilean]] editor, journalist and director of ''[[El Mercurio de Valparaíso]]'' and founder of ''[[El Comercio (Chile)|El Comercio]]''.
== Biography == Tornero was born in [[Valparaíso]], on October 14, 1842. His parents were Carmen Olmos de Aguilera Orrego, and Spanish immigrant José Santos Tornero Monteros, the proprietary of the first public library in Chile. He studied in the National Institute of Santiago, and he later went to France to study on the [[Ecole Superieure de Commerce de Paris]]. He returned to Chile in 1860,<ref name="Biography"/> and he succeeded his father as director of ''[[El Mercurio de Valparaíso]]'' in 1866.<ref name="Historia, Geografía y Ciencias Sociales">{{cite book|title=Historia, Geografía y Ciencias Sociales 2° Educación Media|author=Verónica Méndez Montero, Carolina Santelices Ariztía and Rodrigo Martínez Iturriaga|language=Spanish|publisher=Santillana|year=2009|isbn=978-956-15-1557-4}}</ref> He married Elena Stuven Olmos, and they had 4 children: Carmela, Recaredo, Teresa and Enrique.<ref name="Biography"/>
His father's enterprises included the Spanish Library ({{lang-es|Librería Española}}), the [[printing house]] of ''[[El Mercurio]]'' and the [[Valparaíso]] newspaper of [[El Mercurio de Valparaíso|the same name]]. They remained in the family for 33 years. In 1866, Tornero and his brother Orestes bought the enterprise from their father.<ref name="Biography"/>
Orestes maintained the library and its dependencies, while Recaredo continued administering the printing house and the newspaper.<ref name="Biography"/> Later, they formed Tornero & Sons Society ({{lang-es|Sociedad Tornero e Hijos}}) with his father, who was living in outside Chile.<ref name="Icarito"/>
[[File:Chile Ilustrado main page.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Front page of ''[[Chile Ilustrado]]'' (1872).]]
Since 1867, Tornero was the only editor of ''[[El Mercurio de Valparaíso]]'' until 1870, when he partnered with Camilo Letelier.<ref name="Biography"/> Blanco Cuartín assumed as main editor of the newspaper later; who proposed a cultural and literary-scoped topic.<ref name="Icarito"/>
He published ''[[Chile Ilustrado]]'' in 1872, the first illustrated album of Chile, with a descriptive guide, historic, politic, industrial, social and statistical review of the country and a rich graphic backup,<ref name="Historia, Geografía y Ciencias Sociales"/> with more than 200 wood engravings and 10 lithographs.<ref name="Biography"/> He was awarded for this book on [[1876 Philadelphia Exposition]].<ref name="Icarito"/>
After 9 years as director, he sold his part of the newspaper to Camilo Letelier.<ref name="Icarito"/> He revisited Europe in 1877, where he stayed until 1880.<ref name="Icarito"/> He bought machinery in Europe to create the first paper factory in Chile, after which he began publishing foreign works translated into Spanish.<ref name="Historia, Geografía y Ciencias Sociales"/><ref name="Icarito">{{Cite web |url= http://www.icarito.cl/biografias/articulo/s/2009/12/255-3183-9-santos-tornero-recaredo.shtml |title=Recaredo Santos Tornero |work=Icarito |publisher=[[La Tercera]]/[[COPESA]] |accessdate=27 February 2013 |language=Spanish |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EkbDcgOu|archivedate=27 February 2013|deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="Memoria">{{Cite web |url= http://www.memoriachilena.cl/temas/index.asp?id_ut=chileilustrado(1872):recaredosantostornero |title=Recaredo Santos Tornero: Chile ilustrado - Presentación |work=Memoria Chilena |accessdate=2 July 2010 |language=Spanish|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302085655/http://www.memoriachilena.cl/temas/index.asp?id_ut=chileilustrado%281872%29:recaredosantostornero|archivedate=2 March 2012|deadurl=no }}</ref>
After his comeback to Valparaíso, Tornero established a library and a printing house in Almendral. When his brother Orestes died in 1881, he took over Mercurio library, that was mainly focused on editing teaching books and works translated from French.<ref name="Biography"/>
He founded ''[[El Comercio (Chile)|El Comercio]]'' newspaper in 1890, on the eve of the [[1891 Chilean Civil War]], to support President [[José Manuel Balmaceda]], who had bad relationship with the Chilean press.<ref name="Historia, Geografía y Ciencias Sociales"/>
He died in [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] on July 26, 1902.<ref name="Memoria"/><ref>{{Cite web |url= http://diario.elmercurio.cl/detalle/index.asp?id={00317ab1-381d-4e14-b987-7a29c79efb7c} |title=Hace 100 Años |work=[[El Mercurio|El Mercurio OnLine]] |publisher=Empresa Periodística El Mercurio S.A.P. |accessdate=3 July 2010 }} {{subscription needed}}</ref>

{{about|the inventor|the consumer advocate|Robert S. Adler}}
<!-- FAIR USE of Robert_adler.jpg: see image description page at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Robert_adler.jpg for rationale --> {{Infobox scientist | image = Robert_adler.jpg | caption = Robert Adler | birth_date = December 4, 1913 | birth_place = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | residence = [[United States|U.S.]] | nationality = American -[[Austria]]n | death_date = {{Death date and age|2007|2|15|1913|12|4}} | death_place = [[Boise, Idaho]], [[United States|U.S.]] | field = [[Physics]] | work_institution = [[Zenith Electronics]] | alma_mater = [[University of Vienna]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = None | known_for = wireless [[remote control]] for televisions | prizes = [[Edison Medal]] (1980) | religion = | footnotes = }}
'''Robert Adler''' (December 4, 1913 – February 15, 2007) was an [[Austria]]n-born American inventor who held numerous [[patent]]s. He worked for Zenith retiring as the company's Vice President and Director of Research. His work included developing early sound based remote controls for televisions, which were the standard for 25 years until replaced by IR remotes that could transmit more complex commands.
==Achievements== Adler was born in [[Vienna]] in 1913, the son of Jenny (née Herzmark), a doctor, and Max Adler, a social theorist.<ref name="nytimes">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/20/obituaries/20adler.html|title=The New York Times|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=2015-06-20}}</ref><ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Biographical Dictionary of European Labor Leaders|author=Lane, A.T.|date=1995|volume=1|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=9780313264566|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=VlR8YCE8lkQC|page=8|accessdate=2015-06-20}}</ref><ref>http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/j/o/h/Marshall-John/WEBSITE-0001/UHP-0210.html{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He earned a Ph.D. in [[Physics]] from the [[University of Vienna]] in 1937. Following Austria's annexation by [[Nazi Germany]] in 1939, Dr. Adler, who was [[Jew]]ish,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/744/000165249/|title=Robert Adler|website=www.nndb.com|access-date=2017-02-15}}</ref> left the country. He traveled first to [[Belgium]], then to [[England]], where he acted on the advice of friends, who recommended that he emigrate to the [[United States]].<ref name="inventorspot">{{cite web|url=http://inventorspot.com/adler|title=Inventor of Remote Control: Robert Adler|publisher=inventorspot.com|accessdate=2015-06-20}}</ref> After emigrating to the United States, he began working at [[Zenith Electronics]] in the research division in 1941. In his lifetime, Adler was granted 58 US [[patent]]s.
==Contributions to the remote control== The invention Adler is best known for is the wireless [[remote control]] for [[television]]s. While not the first remote control, its underlying [[technology]] was a vast improvement over previous remote control systems.
The "[[Flash-Matic|Zenith Flash-Matic]]" remote control, invented by [[Eugene Polley]], another [[engineer]] at [[Zenith Electronics|Zenith]], was the first wireless remote control, replacing the signal cable based remote control devices, which never were a success. The Flash-Matic used directional [[flashlight]] in the transmitter device, and photo cells in the television set itself. One of the major shortcomings of this technology was that if the television set was exposed to direct sunlight, it could inadvertently trigger one of the remote control functions. The company president sent the engineers back to the drawing board to come up with a better solution.
[[Image:Zenith Space Commander 600.jpg|thumb|right|A Zenith Space Commander 600 remote control.]] A system based on [[radio waves]] was briefly considered but rejected because the signals could easily travel through walls and could inadvertently change the channel on a neighbor's television. Furthermore, the marketing people at Zenith desired a remote control which did not require batteries, as it was perceived at the time that if the battery died, the customer might think something was wrong with the television set itself.
Adler's solution was to use sound waves to transmit signals to the TV. The first remote control he developed, the "Space Command", used [[aluminum]] rods, analogous to [[tuning fork]]s, struck by hammers toggled by the buttons on the device, to produce high-frequency tones that would be interpreted to control functions on the television set.
In the 1960s, Adler modified the remote control to use [[Ultrasound|ultrasonic]] signals, a technology which went on to be used in television sets manufactured for the next 25 years, until replaced by infrared systems which could transmit more complex commands (but, alas, require batteries to run).
==Professional accomplishments== By the time of his retirement from Zenith, officially in 1982, Adler was the company's Vice President and Director of Research. He remained a technical advisor to Zenith until 1999. In 1980, Adler was awarded the [[Edison Medal]]. In 1997, Adler and Polley were jointly awarded an [[Emmy Award]] by the [[National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]]. Adler's latest patent application was filed on October 6, 2006 for work on [[touch-screen]] technology.<ref>http://appft1.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PG01&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=%2220070024599%22.PGNR.&OS=DN/20070024599&RS=DN/20070024599</ref>
==Death== Robert Adler died in a [[Boise, Idaho]] [[nursing home]] of [[heart failure]] at age 93 years old.
== References == <references />
==External links== *[http://web.mit.edu/invent/iow/adler.html Inventor of the Week Archive - Robert Adler] * {{emmytvlegends name|robert-adler}} *[http://inventorspot.com/node/3977 Robert Adler: Biography of the Inventor Who Made Life Easier for Couch Potatoes] *[http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/16/obit.remote.control.ap/index.html Man who glued TV watchers to the couch dies] *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/16/AR2007021602102.html The Inventor Who Deserves a Sitting Ovation] - ''[[The Washington Post]]'' *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/16/AR2007021602039.html Robert Adler, 94; Engineer, Co-Inventor of TV Remote Control] - ''[[The Washington Post]]'' *[http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article2293441.ece Obituary], ''[[The Independent]]'', 22 February 2007 *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml;jsessionid=KO1LLVRZAUQJZQFIQMGSFFOAVCBQWIV0?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/news/2007/03/13/db1303.xml Obituary], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', 13 March 2007 *[http://tvinterviewsarchive.blogspot.com/2007/02/co-inventor-of-wireless-television.html Obituary and Archive of American Television interview description] *[http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Robert_Adler Biography from IEEE]

'''Robert Boehringer''' (30 July 1884 in [[Winnenden]] – 9 August 1974 in [[Geneva]]) was a German [[industrialist]] and [[poet]].
Boehringer was the son of a factory owner. He spent his childhood, youth, and his student years in [[Basel]], where he also had his Ph.D. approved at the local university. Until 1920 he was the head of the family firm [[Boehringer Ingelheim|C.H. Boehringer]] in [[Ingelheim]]. From 1931 he took part in the establishment of [[Hoffmann-La Roche]] in Basel. In 1930 he settled in Geneva.
After the outbreak of [[World War II]] Boehringer gave up his German citizenship and became a Swiss national. He founded the [[Commission mixte de Secours de la Croix Rouge Internationale]] and after the war he worked for [[Novartis|J. R. Geigy AG]].
From about 1905 Boehringer became a member of the circle of [[Stefan George]] and one of his most trusted friends. After George's death Boehringer became inheritor and administrator of George's estate. In 1959 he established the ''Stefan George Foundation'' and the ''Stefan George Archive''.
Works by Boehringer: „Über das Leben von Gedichten“, „Bildnisse und Nachweise“ and „Das Antlitz des Genius“.
Boehringers papers are held by the [[German Federal Archives]].
==Literature== *Boehringer, Robert: ''Gedenken an Robert Boehringer'', Stefan-George-Stiftung, Stuttgart 1994. Ed. Michael Stettler.
==External links== *[http://www.ingelheim.de/Boehringer-Robert.467.0.html?&L=0%20class%3Dl Short biography, City of Ingelheim] *{{DNB portal|116221860|TYP=}}

'''Robert Newton Anthony''' (September 6, 1916 – December 1, 2006) was an American organizational theorist, and professor of [[management control]] at [[Harvard Business School]], known for his work in the field of [[management control system]]s.<ref name="TAHoF">[http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/robert-newton-anthony/ Robert Newton Anthony] in: ''The Accounting Hall of Fame.'' Accessed 12. 2014.</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Orange, Massachusetts]] to Charles H. and Grace Newton Anthony in 1916, Anthony skipped a grade in elementary school and attended high school in [[Haverhill, Massachusetts]]. There he played the saxophone in the school band, and graduated in 1933 at the age of 16.<ref name="TAHoF"/> In 1938 Anthony graduated from [[Colby College]], and in 1942 received his master's degree in business administration from Harvard, and in 1952 his Doctor of Commercial Science degree.
Anthony was a Harvard Business School faculty member from 1940 to 1982. In 1942 he became research assistant to [[Ross G. Walker]] (1891-1970), Harvard Professor of Business Administration since 1936. After his service in the US Navy from 1943 to 1946 he returned to Harvard, where he was appointed Full professor in 1956. In 1965 he took another leave of absence from Harvard to serve as the [[Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller)|Under Secretary of Defense]] under his friend, Defense Secretary [[Robert McNamara]].<ref name="NYT 2006">Dennis Hevesi, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/18/business/18anthonyobit.html?_r=0 Robert N. Anthony Dies at 90; Made Accounting Easier to Learn]," in ''New York Times,'' Dec. 18, 2006.</ref> In 1973 and 1974, he was president of the [[American Accounting Association]].<ref name="HG 2006">"[http://www.news.harvard.edu/gazette/2006/12.14/15-anthonyobit.html HBS professor, member of Accounting Hall of Fame Robert Anthony dies]" in ''Gazette,'' Harvard University, Dec. 14, 2006.</ref>
== Work == === Planning and management control === Harvard Business School professor [[Regina Herzlinger]] explained about the impact of Anthony's work in the 2006 obituary in the [[Harvard Gazette]]: :''Bob Anthony took a field that was something that only accountants did and transformed it into one that informed top managers in the planning and control of their organizations... He had a monumental impact not only on his students, through his teaching and textbooks, but also on the business, nonprofit, and government worlds through his many influential articles and powerful personal demeanor - his knowledge, intellectual clarity, sense of duty and honor, and managerial perspective.''<ref name="HG 2006"/> And furthermore: :''Bob was also a marvelous writer. He made the murky subject of accounting clear. These exceptional qualities of mind and character, coupled with a Yankee work ethic, helped him to transform the field of managerial accounting from the province of accountants to the tool of managers.''<ref name="HG 2006"/> And Harvard accounting professor [[Charles Christenson]] added: :''Bob did more than anyone else to introduce a conceptual structure to management control. In his numerous publications, he has ranged across all the important questions. 'Management Control in Industry Research Organizations,' for example, examined the problem of measuring intellectual output - a much more difficult task than measuring more tangible output. His 1965 book, 'Planning and Control Systems,' became the bible of the field.<ref name="HG 2006"/>
=== Comptroller at the US Department of Defense === In 1965 Anthony served as [[comptroller]] at the [[US Department of Defense]] under Robert S. McNamara, where he supervised the quality of accounting and financial reporting of the organization. Antony was credited for aligning the accounting service among the five military services. [[Charles Christenson]] explained: :''He changed the way the Defense Department operated... There was a substantial cost overrun on the [[LGM-30 Minuteman|Minuteman missile program]]. Secretary McNamara wanted procedures to keep that from happening again. Bob made sure all the branches were on the same wavelength.''<ref name="NYT 2006"/>
== Selected publications == Anthony wrote or had a role in writing 27 books on accounting and management control. A selection: * Anthony, Robert Newton. ''Planning and control systems: a framework for analysis.'' (1965). * Anthony, Robert Newton, and James S. Reece. ''Management accounting: text and cases.'' Irwin, 1970. * Anthony, Robert Newton, Glenn A. Welsch, and James S. Reece. ''Fundamentals of management accounting.'' RD Irwin, 1974. * Anthony, Robert Newton, John Dearden, and Norton M. Bedford. ''Management control systems.'' RD Irwin, 1980. * Anderson, Charles A., and Robert Newton Anthony. ''The new corporate directors: Insights for board members and executives.'' Wiley, 1986. * Anthony, Robert Newton, and David W. Young. ''Management control in nonprofit organizations.'' Vol. 4. Homewood, IL: Irwin, 1988. * Anthony, Robert Newton. ''The management control function.'' Boston: Harvard Business School Press, 1988.
==Archives and records== *[http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:HBS.Baker.EAD:bak00052 Robert N. Anthony papers] at Baker Library Special Collections, Harvard Business School
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/18/business/18anthonyobit.html?_r=0 New York Times, obituary], 18.12.2006
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Sam Nazarian | image = Sam_Nazarian.JPG | image_size = 250px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1975}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | citizenship = [[United States|American]] | religion. = [[Christianity]] | residence = [[Beverly Hills, California]] | alma_mater = [[University of Southern California]] | years_active = | occupation = [[SBE Entertainment Group]] | salary = | spouse = [[Emina Cunmulaj]] | website = [http://SBE.com SBE.com] | parents = [[Younes Nazarian]] | relatives = [[Izak Parviz Nazarian]] | footnotes = | signature = }} '''Sam Nazarian''' (born 1975) is an [[Iranian-American]] businessman, investor and philanthropist. He is the Founder, Chairman and CEO of [[SBE Entertainment Group]].
==Biography== ===Early life=== Nazarian was born to a [[Persian Jewish]] family in [[Tehran]] in 1975.<ref name=WMag>[http://www.wmagazine.com/people/2005/08/sam_nazarian/ W Magazine: "Nazarian: Sam I Am - Young tycoon Sam Nazarian has big dreams for himself, L.A. and the world" by Christopher Bagley] Aug 2005</ref> The Nazarian family immigrated to the United States following the [[Iranian Revolution]].<ref name=BloombergSleep>[https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/magazine/sam-nazarian-wants-you-to-sleep-with-him-12012011.html Bloomberg: "Sam Nazarian Wants You to Sleep with Him" By Karl Taro Greenfeld] December 01, 2011</ref> He is the son of [[Younes Nazarian]] who made a fortune along with his brother [[Izak Parviz Nazarian]] as an early investor in [[Qualcomm]].<ref name=BloombergSleep /> He was raised in [[Beverly Hills, California]] where he attended [[Beverly Hills High School]] and later studied at the [[University of Southern California]].<ref name=WMag />
==Career== ===Telecommunications=== His first entrepreneurial venture was in 1998, when he invested a little bit of money into Platinum Wireless, a [[telecommunications]] business specializing in the distribution of [[Nextel]] software. Within one year of its founding, Platinum Wireless was the number one Nextel distributor in Southern California. He then entered the world of real estate by diversifying his family's assets into real estate holdings, beginning with the establishment of 3Wall Development in 1999. Under Sam's guidance 3Wall became one of Southern California's largest owners of multi-family housing.
===Hospitality=== SBE owns several Los Angeles nightclubs and lounges: ''Create'', ''Greystone Manor'', ''Emerson'', ''Hyde'', ''XIV'', ''Colony'', ''Eden'', ''MyHouse'', ''MyStudio'' and ''The Abbey''. As clubs tend to wane in popularity quickly, Nazarian typically only keeps his clubs open for eight months to a year, closes them for extensive renovations, and then reopens them (often under a new name, preferably short) to keep the brand fresh.<ref name=smallhours>{{Cite news|first=James|last=Verini|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jul/29/entertainment/et-smallhours29|title=SMALL HOURS; Enjoy his clubs while you can; Sam Nazarian keeps his many places trendy by constantly reinventing them|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=July 29, 2006|page=E1}}</ref> SBE generally owns each of its venues outright giving it the flexibility to quickly adjust to the vagaries of the market.<ref name=smallhours /> These venues continue to see a high level of popularity and celebrity patronage, as well as being frequently visited by the characters of [[HBO]]'s ''[[Entourage (U.S. TV series)|Entourage]]''. Nazarian made an appearance as himself greeting the main characters of the show in the episode "[[No Cannes Do]]". Nazarian's SBE brand has also been featured on episodes of ''[[The Hills (TV series)|The Hills]]''. Nazarian owns the Hyde Lounge at Staples Center in Los Angeles<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/dec/11/entertainment/la-et-night11-2009dec11|title=Hyde Lounge at Staples Center|last=LeTellier|first=Alexandra|date=2009-12-11|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-08-21|last2=Shatkin|first2=Elina|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> and he also owns the Hyde at AmericanAirlines Arena in Miami.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miami.com/miami-news/hyde-nightclub-opening-at-american-airlines-arena-9867/|title=Hyde nightclub opening at American Airlines Arena|date=2012-04-18|work=Miami.com|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en}}</ref> In 2014, SBE agreed to lease the top two floors of [[5900 Wilshire]], a skyscraper in Los Angeles, CA.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2014/jan/08/business/la-fi-variety-sbe-20140109|title=Nightclub owner SBE to replace Variety at 5900 Wilshire|last=Vincent|first=Roger|date=2014-01-08|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
====Restaurants==== He has secured partnerships with [[Philippe Starck]] and chefs Katsuya Uechi, [[José Andrés]] and [[Michael Mina]]. His partnership with Katsuya and [[Starck]] resulted in the restaurant Katsuya, with locations in Brentwood, Hollywood, Glendale, downtown Los Angeles and downtown San Diego. XIV, in partnership with Chef [[Michael Mina]], opened on the [[Sunset Strip]] in October 2008.<ref name="sbe.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sbe.com/execs/samnaz.html|title=SBE Corporate}}</ref> Nazarian opened The Bazaar with [[José Andrés]], which is integrated into SLS Hotel in Beverly Hills, in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://la.eater.com/archives/2008/04/25/the_bazaar_at_sls_beverly_hills_rendered.php|title=The Bazaar at SLS Beverly Hills, Rendered}}</ref> SBE is also invested in hamburger chain [[Umami Burger]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Gelt|first=Jessica|title=Umami Burger's brand sizzles with SBE backing|date=August 11, 2011|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/2011/aug/11/food/la-fo-sbe-umami-20110811|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HCottpdO?url=http://articles.latimes.com/print/2011/aug/11/food/la-fo-sbe-umami-20110811|archivedate=June 7, 2013|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
====Hotels==== [[SLS Las Vegas]], [[SLS Brickell]], [[SLS Lux]], SLS Beverly Hills and SLS South Beach.
Redbury Hollywood, Redbury South Beach and Redbury New York.
Raleigh Hotel Miami Beach and Townhouse Hotel Miami Beach.
===Producer=== Nazarian has served as [[executive producer]] for the films ''[[Waiting... (film)|Waiting...]],'' ''[[Down in the Valley (film)|Down in the Valley]]'', ''[[Five Fingers (2006 film)|Five Fingers]],'' ''[[The Last Time (film)|The Last Time]]'', ''[[Pride (2007 film)|Pride]]'', ''[[Mr. Brooks]]'' and ''[[College (2008 film)|College]]''.
===Honors=== In 2006, Nazarian was honored as the youngest executive to be named one of the "Top 100 Most Powerful People in Southern California" by ''[[Los Angeles Times Magazine|West]],''<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/aug/13/magazine/tm-toppower33/20|title=WEST, The Power Issue|date=August 13, 2006}}</ref> the ''[[Los Angeles Times Magazine]],'' and was named among "The Influentials.".<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.lamag.com/featuredarticle.aspx?id=17778&page=1|journal=[[Los Angeles Magazine]]|title=The 122 Most Influential People in LA|date=December 2009}}</ref> Since 2008, Nazarian has served on the Board of Directors of the [[Southern California Institute of Architecture]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://la.curbed.com/2008/2/20/10577364/local-dudes-mak|title=Local Dudes Make Good: Caruso to USC, Nazarian to SCI-Arc|last=jwilliams|date=2008-02-20|website=Curbed LA|access-date=2017-08-10}}</ref> The Beverly Hills High School basketball court was renamed "Sam Nazarian Court" after Nazarian, a 1993 Beverly Hills High School graduate, made a $200,000 donation to the Beverly Hills Athletic Alumni Association.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/education/la-me-beverly-hills-names-20150203-story.html|title=Along with his name on Beverly Hills campuses, donor buys controversy|last=Ceasar|first=Stephen|date=2015-02-03|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-08-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> In July 2009, Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa appointed Nazarian to the Board of Airport Commissioners of Los Angeles World Airports. In 2014, Nazarian was named to ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'''s 40 Under 40 list.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=October 2014|title=40 Under 40|url=http://fortune.com/40-under-40/sam-nazarian-27/}}</ref>
==Personal life== He is married to [[Albanian American]] model, [[Emina Cunmulaj]];<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/confidential/king-clubs-plays-ace-wedding-article-1.2267286 New York Daily News: "King of clubs Sam Nazarian throws an ace party for Mexico wedding to model Emina Cunmulaj" BY Marianne Garvey] June 23, 2015</ref> they have two daughters.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=1343092|name=Sam Nazarian}} *[http://www.sbe.com/ SBE Official Website]
